But Love's a fire, and if it burns within
'Twill ſmoke without; do you ſee any ſmoke?
Or in my looks one ſign of inward Torment?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Not the leaſt, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I am very glad of it.
My looks are honeſt then, and tell no falſhoods.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I wiſh your Heart were but as faultleſs, Madam,
As your looks are.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: My Heart will ſerve my turn.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Yes, it has ſerv'd your turn, for it has turn'd
And turn'd, and turn'd, but always to the Sun.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Think and report it too, rather I had
A thouſand times be thought ambitious, perjur'd,
Than ſuch a wretch as a forſaken Woman.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Madam, I'le do you right.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You will oblige me,
And your ſelf too, never to ſee me more;
For I ſhall ever vex your haughty heart.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Well, Madam, I will make a ſhift to bear it;
But you by this, give me to underſtand
I am a Storm that trouble your Delights,
You cannot ſing your Songs to your new Lover,
With ſuch a Thorn as I am at your Breaſt.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Oh! you conjecture wrong, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No, Madam.
Well, I will leave you; my tempeſtuous Breath
Shall not ruffle your Bridal Curtains.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Oh! you cannot;
Nor blow but one looſe Feather from my pillow.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Oh! Yes! yes! I will go! but wou'd it not
Be for your eaſe to ſend your Conſcience with me?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Your own is heavier than you well can carry.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But yours, I fear is murder'd; If it be,
It's Ghoſt will make your Glories burn as dim
As Lamps that faint when an ill Spirit appears.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Well, ſtay or go, I'le not talk with you, of you,
Look on you, think upon you, any more.—

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Madam, the Dauphin's asking for your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Oh! e're I ſee him, I muſt pour my grief out,
For my heart's full, and it is running over.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: So, Now the worſt is paſt.—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Was ever falſhood
Dreſt in ſuch gorgeous ſwelling Robes of arrogance?
It is ſo big, no ſlender Robes can fit it.
Now ſorrow thou haſt found a paſſage to me,
All other wayes my Soul was inacceſſible.
Fame I contemn, her Temple is a Brothel,
Where good and bad lie mingled all together.
Victory I ſcorn, I am not proud; mankind
Is capable of Cowardiſe, and Death.
Titles I ſcorn, they are often fixt to Pamphlets.
Beauty is the only thing that conquer's me,
I am diſarm'd by a white brittle Wand,
Vanquiſh't and robb'd of all, and then forſaken.
Still there's ſome chink made in us ſons of ſin,
For Miſery and Death to enter in.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: FArewel oh! World, thou School of bearded Boys,
Here empty Fools are honour'd for full Baggs,
And well-fill'd minds deſpiſ'd for empty pockets;
Men's eyes are dim, but Women's blind to excellence.
This beautious Woman look'd upon my Head
And ſaw no Crown on it, and look'd no deeper.
Thus are our Sex by Women oft deceiv'd,
The Gallant thinks his Miſtreſs ſees his Qualities,
She only ſees his Equipage and Garniture.
Th 'old wooden Lord, ſees a young Beauty glance
He thinks on him; Alas! 'Tis on a toy,
More wooden than himſelf, his Coronet.
The Stateſman think's his great parts charm his Miſtreſs,
She only look's on's great Houſe, his great Train.
The brave young Hero think's his Miſtreſs value's him,
Becauſe his Courage can ſupport her Honour;
'Tis for his Pages to hold up her Tayle.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: All things, my Lord, are ready for your Journey.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I'me ready then: Now will I ſeek ſome place
Where I may nevermore ſee any thing
Like Man or Woman; ſpecially like Woman,
In ſome dark Forreſt will I live, whoſe Shades
May guard my Eyes ſecurely from the Moon,
Becauſe 'tis bright, and changing like a Woman;
Therefore I'le never ſee 't but in Eclipſe.
Barren ſhall be the Earth, and ſo bemum'd
And mortifi'd with ſhade, not all the Court-ſhip
Nor golden proffers of the Sun ſhall woe it,
Or bribe it to one ſmile; becauſe if Flattery,
Riches and Pomp, can gain it, 'tis a Woman.
I will want breath, e're let the winds approach me,
Becauſe they'r like th' inconſtant ſight of Woman.
I never will ſee Summers vaniſhing dew,
Nor Winters ſhining Ice, 'cauſe both, like Woman.
The Dew turn's Air when once the Sun has kiſs'd it.
And Woman in enjoyment proves Deluſion,
Something leſs real than the dreams of fancy.
The Ice diſſolves under the Sun's bright ſmiles.
And Woman always yield's when glory tempt's,
And then what e're is built upon her ſink's.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Monſieur La Marre, my Lord, attends without.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: La Marre? What has that Fool to do with me?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He ſay's he has a Meſſage from the King.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He lyes, the King would ſend a wiſer Meſſenger;
But ſince he uſe's the King's Name, admit him.
sp.stage: Serv. goes out and introudces La Marre.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: Now I'le eſtabliſh a firm Intereſt in him.
Your Grace's moſt obedient humble Servant,
I am extreamly joyful for your Graces
Glorious ſuceeſs; your Grace ha's done ſtrange Marvels;
His Majeſty has a very vaſt eſteem for you,
He and I have talk't of you a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir; Well, to be ſhort, good Sir,
Have you any buſineſs with me?

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: To be ſhort,
There is no perſon in the World, my Lord,
More in eſteem both with the King and Dauphin,
And for my own part.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: For your part, I mean, Sir,
Have you any buſineſs with me?

sp.speaker: La M
sp.l: Buſineſs, my Lord!
Only that I'me your Graces humble ſervant;
And ſo forth, and to pay my high reſpects,
And ſo forth, and ſo forth—I know your Grace
Ha's heard the great Court news, the Dauphin's Marriage
With Madamoiſelle de Guiſe is now made publick.
Truth is, ſhe is a very curious creature.
Devil take me if ſhe be not.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Now I find it.
This ſenceleſs Rogue is put on to abuſe me.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: What think's your Grace?
Wou'd not ſo ſweet a Creature
Refreſh you finely after a Campagne?
In ſhort, there will be a great Ball to night,
The King, the Dauphin, and his beauteous Bride,
Do all expect your Grace to be a Dancer.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Plain, plain abuſe! Sir, When was I a Dancer?
My foot ſhall dance upon no Earth but this.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: How? Kick, my Lord?
What do you mean by this?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You are put on by ſome to abuſe me, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: You are put on by ſome to abuſe me rather:
My Lord, I do not underſtand the meaning of it;
I ſhall not put up this.—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Shall you not, Sir?
sp.stage: The Duke offers to draw. La Marre putts up.

sp.speaker: La M.
sp.l: I ſhall at preſent, but the King ſhall know this.
I am more conſiderable with the King
Than you believe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Indeed there are in Court
Too many ſuch ſoft Heads as yours embroyder'd,
And made State-Cuſhions, for great men to lean on;
And Fortune often jump's from Heaven upon 'em.

sp.speaker: La M.
sp.l: Soft Heads, and Cuſhions!
Come, my Lord, be it known to you
His Majeſties Servants are not to be call'd
Fools and Soft-heads, by e're a Peer of you all.
The King ſhall know this; He'l not take it well.
All this is, cauſe I did affront his Father,
I'le do his Fathers buſineſs for this trick.—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I find all Courts, are apt, like all great Mountains,
To breed ſuch little Cattel; and theſe Runts
Do often draw weighty Affairs along.
But oh! the Inſolence of this Vile Woman,
To ſet her fools upon me, to abuſe me?
Oh! there is Thunder forming in my Soul,
Now ſhou'd I meet my Father and his Firebrands,
Off ſhou'd I go, and rend the Court in pieces.
He ſaid, he'd bring me hither his Conſpirators,
I'le run for fear the ſtrong Temptation ſeize me.
sp.stage: The Scene is drawn, the Dauphin and Louize are ſat in State, and entertain'd with Muſick and Dancing. The Entertainment ended, Enter the Duke, He ſees the Dauphin Careſſing Louize.

lg.l: LOng, long had great Amintor lain,
At Celia's feet, and wept in vain;
Not all his Youth, his Love, or Glory,
But once cou'd make her hear his Story.
One ſmile ſhe to that Youth deny'd,
For whom a thouſand Beauties dyed. Chor.
Yet all the while fair Celia prov'd,

l.hi: So haughty, ſo cruel, ſhe ſecretly Lov'd.

lg.l: Still, ſtill he bravely bore his Pain,
With Patience took her proud Diſdain,
Though all her Looks with Wounds did fill him,
And every Word did almoſt kill him,
To ſee her, or to hear her Speak.
He was content his Heart ſhou'd break. Chor.
Yet all the while fair Celia prov'd,

l.hi: So haughty, ſo cruel, ſhe ſecretly Lov'd.

lg.l: But beautiful Celia now fearing,
His Heart ſhould grow hard with long bearing;
Not willing to Loſe him,
Doe's gentlier Uſe him,
And drive's away all his Diſpairing.
Oh now, brave Amintor, no Pitty afford,
Thou haſt got her by Storm, now put all to th' Sword;
To the Altar of Modeſty, if ſhe wou'd fly,
It is but an Image, and there let her dye.
Now Celia for Pitty is crying;
But oh! the Delight of that Dying!
Her Soul cannot ſhew it,
Her ſoul doe's not know it,
Her Soul in a Rapture is flying.
Love, like the Great Turk, in his Pleaſures doe's ſport,
With Mutes, in the innermoſt parts of his Court;
He drives the dull Counſellor, Thinking, away,
And himſelf and his Mutes, out o' Breath he doe's play.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Oh! What infernal Spirit brought me hither?
I am decreed for Wickedneſs; I ſhall
Deſtroy that Prince, in ſpite of all that poor
Court Houſhold-ſtuff, that Imagery about him.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Ha! Vendoſme there? Leave me a while, my Love.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I will, but I will watch you do not hurt him.
For ſtill I love him, ſpight of all his falſhood.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He's coming! My Heart ſwells, that my Ribbs bend
Like Bowes of Steel, ready to ſhoot my Soul at him.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Sir, you have long ſor'd or'e my head, but now
I'le bring you down; Where is your Commiſſion?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How? My Commiſſion? Where it ſhall remain
Till the King takes it; Sir, in my own keeping.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: How? Shall?
sp.stage: Dauphin puts his Hand to his Sword.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Oh! hold, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: What doſt thou mean?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Oh! to hurt him will pierce your Father's heart;
I beg you then, upon my knees, be calm.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: What Storm ſo rude, which ſuch a beautious Halcyon
Cannot ſoon calme? Traytor, this Angel here
Has given thee life; But know, thou art preſerv'd
To periſh with thy Father on a Scaffold.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I'le ſave him too from that, or periſh with him

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Now a brave Fool, that had more Blood than Brains,
Whoſe ſoul lay in his Arm, not in his Head,
And had my Wrongs, and my Power to revenge 'em,
Wou'd thruſt his fooliſh Arm to reach Revenge,
Though he pull'd all the Kingdom on his Head;
He wou'd accept the March, the Devil offers me
Inſtead of my loſt Miſtreſs, his own Daughter,
The Heireſs of all Hell, Rebellion;
I, the next minute, cou'd confound the Town
Into a Temple o' Death, and marry her in it;
And with her, get the Riches of all France.
And Hell has ſent to Treat about the Match.
His Kindred, curſed Paſſions to my Heart
Here come his Agents on the ſame Affair.
Mountain on Mountain, pil'd to ſcale my Honeſty.
sp.stage: Enter the Great Conſtable, La Force, and Conſpirators.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Son! Here are all our Friends.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Away with you,
You ſcare my Loyalty out of its Wits.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Thy Loyalty? Thou art afraid, I ſee;
Theſe are the honeſt Friends I told thee off.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: You mean the Traytours.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Yes, ſuch you promis'd me,
And I give Men and Things their proper Names.
Scuffle for the World then how you will, you Traytors,
There was but one ſweet Spot in it I valued,
And it is ſunk beneath me; all the reſt
Take he that will, and how, I do not care.
Go turn the Globe about then how you will,
There ſhall be in this wide World, one honeſt Man,
Though he has much a doe to keep his Honeſty.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, come back again.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: No, I have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Thy thoughts?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: My thoughts.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: And art thou ſuch a Fool?
What doſt thou in a Court, or in the World?
Go be a Monk, in hope of being Sainted,
Give Fryers all thy Gold, in the rich hopes
When thou art dead, they'l tippe thy Scull with Silver;
Stink all thy Life, to be ador'd when Dead,
And have thy rotten Bones to Cure lame Leggs.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Do you go joyn your plotting Heads and loſe'em.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: Is this your fooling him ſo admirably?
How chance we let him go, and did not kill him?
Graves have no Ecchoes, Sculls want Coverings
Of Fleſh and Blood, but hide a Secret better.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I'le Kill him with more pleaſure than I Got him.
I Got him? I ner'e got him, he's a Baſtard;
No Honeſty cou'd ever ſpring from me.

sp.speaker: 1. Conſp.
sp.l: Curſe on his Piety.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Some Prieſt begot him,
Lay with his Mother when ſhe ſlept at Prayers,
That makes the World appear a Dream to him.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: The Mother is the chief Ingredient in him.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I ought not to get Children of a Woman,
I ought to mix with nothing but a Chaos,
And get Confuſion to the Univerſe,
And then the Children wou'd be like the Father.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: I ner'e approved truſting ſo rank a Secret
To ſuch a tender Mind; I knew 't wou'd gripe him
His Conſcience wou'd have Qualm's.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Ay, there's the thing!
We breed our Children's Minds as tenderly
And Womaniſh as their Bodies; he who means
To have a gallant Son, muſt plunge his Soul
Or'e head and ears betimes in Wickedneſs,
Then when he is a Man 'twill be his Element.
He muſt not let him go wrapp'd warm in Silk
Spun from the ſilly Worms in a Prieſts Head,
But go ſtark naked, then he'll feel no cold.
For Conſcience is but the Soul's outward Skin
Uſe it to Nakedneſs, it feels no Weather,
Uſe it to Labour, and it never Bliſters.
If I had us'd this Fool to ſin, I might
Have lodg'd my Treaſon in his brawny Head
As ſafe as Poyſon in an Aſſe's Hoofe.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: But now it crack's his chryſtal Wit, and ſpills.
I hate theſe chriſtal Wits, they are good for nothing
But to make flattering Looking-glaſſes for Ladies.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: He ſay's he'll keep his honeſty; damn'd Sot!
What will he do with it? Go beg with it?
For in this Age 'tis of no other uſe,
But like a Beggar's Child, to move Compaſſion,
Yet never gaines the half it coſt in keeping,
For all Men will ſuſpect it for a Baſtard.
sp.stage: Enter an Officer with a Guard.

sp.speaker: Off. and the Gua.
sp.l: Reſign your ſelves my Lords;
You are my Priſoners.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: How Sir? Your Priſoners?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Your own Son, my Lord,
Charges you with High Treaſon againſt the King,
And bloody cruelties to Count Briſac.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! curſed Villain!

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: Villaines both of you.

sp.speaker: 1. Conſp.
sp.l: You are, you have betray'd us all.
All Betray'd.

sp.speaker: 2. Conſp.
sp.l: A trick to ruine us, and beg our Fortu ••

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: How! Are you laughing at us?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Yes; I am.

sp.speaker: 1. Conſp.
sp.l: You did deſign we ſhou'd be ſeiz'd then?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Yes.
And I laugh heartily to ſee you all Sigh,
As you were bottling up Air in your Bellyes
To ſerve you when your Wind-pipes are cork'd up.
But come poor Men, be comforted, all's well.
I ramm'd this Fool up to the mouth with Treaſon,
Not to hurt us, but to break him in Pieces.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: So Sir, Your Son informs me ex'lent things of you.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Art thou, unnatural Monſter, my Accuſer?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I am; The ſecrets tore out of my Breaſt
And broke all Barrs of Nature.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! vile Wretch!
Seek to deſtroy his Being, who gave thee thine?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What greater Curſe than Being cou'd you give me,
With all the Plagues your ſins entayle upon it.
You ſpent your own and all my ſins beforehand
And morgag'd me to Hell before you got me,
For more than I was worth.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Thou mak'ſt me mad!

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ambition makes you ſo.
If I had that diſeaſe, I'de have my Head
Trepan'd, to let out all the windy Vapours,
Rather than ſwell ſo big, till my Brains crack.
sp.stage: Enter the Dauphin, La Marre, and Train.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Where's the Conſtable? bold daring Traytor!
And haſt thou dar'd to wrack the Man I lov'd,
For whoſe leaſt hair I took thy Head in pawn?
Know I will have thee broken on the Wheele,
If thou haſt dar'd only to break his ſleep.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I am contented.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Why! Is he not hurt?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Did not you inform me,
You ſaw him newly taken from the Wrack?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: You did; then it was you that wrackt him.
If ſo, Sir, you have ſerv'd me a fine trick,
To torture him and put it upon me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But, Sir, he ſaie's you put it upon me,
And ſought by that to tempt him into Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I never tempted him nor talk'd with him.
I ſcarce have ſeen him ſince he came to Court.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I am amaz'd!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: What jugling's here between you?

sp.speaker: D.
sp.l: I'me half afraid he has put ſome trick upon me.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: You ſee he's ſilent, Sir, he know's not what
To ſay, nor I to think. Well, I've obſerv'd
Theſe damn'd half witted and half honeſt fellows,
Like Africa, have things of different kind
Meet and engender, and get monſters in 'em.
Their wit and folly couple, and get non-ſence,
With a ſtrange face of ſence; their knavery and honeſty.
Beget a Devil with an honeſt look,
And ſuch a Monſter is this fellow's lye.
Or elſe perhap's he is a down-right Traytor,
And is a partner in Briſac's Conſpiracy,
And he wou'd make my Bloud the Aqua fortis
To eat his partners Priſon bars aſunder.
I believe that.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Come, you are Villain's both.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: A'nt pleaſe your Highneſs, you have hit upon it.
The Duke of Vendoſme affronted me this morning
Only becauſe I mention'd you with honour;
I told him I wou'd find a time to tell you.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Who bids you meddle? give away that fellows
Employment preſently.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: Give away my Employment?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Be gon, Sir,

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: Sir it coſt me five years purchaſe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Be gon, Sir.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: Sir, I have had no ſalary
Since I came in it.

sp.speaker: 1. Courtier.
sp.l: Stand prating to the King?
Out of the preſence.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: Sir, I've paid for prating.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Well, if you have, Sir, go prate ſomewhere elſe.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: Here's a fine buſineſs, turn'd away for Loyalty.
Well, I will be reveng'd upon the Court.
I know ſome Male-contents that I will ſtick to.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Now, to conclude the ſtrife, open thoſe doors.
sp.stage: The Scene is drawn, and Briſac is ſitting dreſt, awake, and well.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This ſight, or th'other was a ſtrange Deluſion,

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Witchcraft, you know I traffick with the Devil.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I am amaz'd at this! How do's Briſac?
Vendoſme reported that his Father wrack'd thee.

sp.speaker: Briſac.
sp.l: He threatned me indeed, but durſt not do it.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Some damn'd deſign was forg'd between 'em both;
I'le truſt thee to him no longer.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I'me convinc't:
You tamperd with your Son, and put ſome trick on him.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: So, I am ſtill judg'd guilty, though my Innocence
Has paſt the Ordeal of the burning noon;
Ha's trod the Light unſcorch't!—Oh! equal doings.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: If thou beeſt innocent, thy Son's a Cannibal,
Who feed's his Greatneſs with his Fathers fleſh;
And to the horrid feaſt, invites the King,
'Tis ſo! 'tis ſo! the Monſter, Sir, abuſes you,
He gives you Philters in his Father's Scul,
And you drink down the damn'd bewitching draught.
Throw 't up again, if you will keep your Crown.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I'le keep my Crown, and therefore I will keep
Him who protects my Crown from thy Ambition.
Come in, I gueſs the meaning of this Riddle.
sp.stage: The King goes out leading the Duke.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Not all this do?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: And ſhall this potent ſlave
Still rule the King, and trample upon me?
I'le make his Father ruine him. [Aſide.] My Lord,
I find you were miſ-repreſented to me.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I'me glad you find it, Sir, your noble Youth
Has not yet play'd enough with the World's Tennis Ball,
To know its curſed Tricks.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: I am convinc'd,
Your Son's the Villain, that I thought you were.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I'me now convinc't of it to my great ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: He blackens you, to make himſelf ſeem bright.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: And, Sir, 'twas he that blackned you to me.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Oh! Villain!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Now I find his tricks; He ſecretly
Puts Pirats Colours out at both our Sterns,
That we might fight each other in miſtake,
Then he ſhou'd ſhare the Ruines of us both!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: I will remove him.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! By all means, Sir.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: My Father's Old, What then? Age like a Caterpiller
Will crawl upon the Leaves of a young Tree
'Till it has eaten away all it's Beauty;
And I'le not waſt my golden youth in Bondage,
To a proud ſlave.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: T'were better he were damn'd.
Had I more Sons, than wou'd Eclipſe the Sun,
I'de kill 'em all, if they ſtood in your Light.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: That's nobly ſaid.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I'le do as well; the King
Shall ſend this ſlave e're night to the Baſtile.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Do this, and you and I will ſhare the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Sir, let me ſhare your Heart, that's all I ask.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: You ſhall have that, and all that France can give.
sp.stage: The Conſtable kiſſes the Dauphin's hand,

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: How's this? he's great again! he's wound himſelf
Into the Dauphin's Favour, who abhor'd him.

sp.speaker: 2. Court.
sp.l: Who ever thought this had been poſſible?

sp.speaker: 3. Cou.
sp.l: Nothing's impoſſible to this damn'd Conſtable.

sp.speaker: 1. Cou.
sp.l: He'l be more abſolute than e're he was.—
Well I will be the firſt ſhall ſtrike in with him.
Gentlemen, I'me glad to ſee this ſight.
The Conſtable's a man of excellent parts.
Devil take his parts, and him—

sp.speaker: 2. Cou.
sp.l: Oh! moſt rare parts.
Pox on his parts. He'l ſtick on all our skirts.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: My Lord, from this time forward I'me your Friend.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: And I your Highneſſes moſt faithful ſlave.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Sir, Are you in earneſt with him?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Ask no Queſtions.
sp.stage: The Courtiers run all and ſalute the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: My Lord! my Lord.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! now the Flyes come buzzing!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: My Lord, your Grace's humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Buzze!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: My Lord! my Lord!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Nay Gentlemen, ſtart fair,
Don't think you are in a progreſs; carve me hanſomly.

sp.speaker: 1. Cou.
sp.l: My Lord, believe me, I'me your Grace's ſervant.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I know it, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Cou.
sp.l: I am indeed, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I'le take my Oath on't.

sp.speaker: 2. Cou.
sp.l: My Lord, I honour your Grace moſt particularly.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Particular Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: 3. Cou.
sp.l: Oh! my Lord, I honour you,
And ever did with all my heart and ſoul.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Sir, You and I have but one Soul between us.

sp.speaker: 3. Cou.
sp.l: Nay! I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Pylades and Oreſtes.

sp.speaker: 1. Cou.
sp.l: Your Grace is pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! your Worſhips Jeſter.

sp.speaker: 2. Cou.
sp.l: Damn him, he laugh's at's all!
I'le ſcrape no more to him.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Out! out you ſilly Raſcals, do you hope
To ſell your Leggs, and Bows, and Nods to me?
Were but your Leggs as rotten as your Hearts,
I'de pull 'em off, and beat you about the heads with 'em,
For thinking you cou'd pawme ſuch ſtuffe on me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: What? what?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Out! out! I ſay, you Flies! you Maggots.
This Greatneſs is a perfect Holland Cheeſe,
Pour Wine into't, and it breeds Maggots preſently.
The Dauphin only pour'd ſome ſmiles into me,
And ſee how ſoon the Maggots crawl about me.
Well, han't I brought you off?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: To Admiration.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: Now I ſhall dare to truſt my Fortunes with you, once more.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: How, truſt your Fortunes! you may venture
To have your Heads cut off, if I adviſe you,
For I have tricks to put 'em on again,
And put 'em on better than e're they were.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: I had rather keep mine on juſt as it is.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Now I will tell you how I fool'd my Son.
I caſt Briſac into deep ſleep with Opium,
Then ſhew'd him as if taken from the Wrack,
Thinking that way to fool him: if I could not;
I laid a Trap for him to fool himſelf.
So every way I rid the Mule, and made him
Carry me up the Alps of my Deſigns.
I'me now about a Plot ſhall take effect;
You'l ſee th'event with ſpeed.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: Farwel 'till then.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Now to my Work, here comes my Inſtrument.

sp.speaker: La Gua.
sp.l: My Conſcience! Conſcience!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Now what ail's your Conſcience?
Theſe little Souls wear great long proking Conſciences,
That make 'em ſtumble every ſtep they go.
Away with thy fool's bauble of a Conſcience,
A Horn-book is not ſo ridiculous;
Thy Mother tyed it to thee in thy Childhood,
And thou art ſuch an Aſſe to wear it ſtill.
Away with it, and do me one more kindneſs.

sp.speaker: La Gua.
sp.l: I'le do you no more kindneſſes.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: You ſhall.
Do not refuſe me, for fear I uſe you ſcurvily.

sp.speaker: La Gua.
sp.l: What dare you do?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Do not you dare to truſt.
You I have faſt; your Lover is my ſlave,
And he ſhall to the Gallyes.

sp.speaker: La Gua.
sp.l: To the Gallyes!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: What, to prevent me, you'l complain perhaps
How ill I uſe perſons of Quality,
A noble Knight, and Lady of the poſt.

sp.speaker: La Gua.
sp.l: Of your own dubbing.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Who are very dextrous
At any knavery, and to keep your Lover
You'l have his Ears nail'd to the Pillory.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: Oh! baſe! baſe man! Now dare not I refuſe him.
Well, What is this ſweet buſineſs I muſt do?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: To bring the Princeſs and my Son together,
And when in talk their Spirits begin to mount,
And get a proſpect of the treachery,
Confeſs it all, and lay it on the Dauphin.

sp.speaker: La Gua.
sp.l: And what if your Son kills me?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: How? He kill thee?
Ah! poor tame fool, he will not kill a Flea.

sp.speaker: La Gua.
sp.l: Nay, he is not ſo bloudy a man as you are.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Well, let him be as bloudy as he will,
I'le guard thee ſafely: take thy Lover then
And fly whither you will, I'le yearly give you
A Penſion ſhall maintain you in ſuch Equipage,
That go to England, and thy Love ſhall paſs
For a French Count, thou for a French Counteſs.
See my Son comes, go fetch the Princeſs preſently.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: Well, this ſhall be the laſt foul trick I'le play. Ex.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I'le go! I'le go! Farwel my Fortunes, Honours,
Succeſſes, Glories, Power▪ gawdy Raggs,
Which all together▪ make up one fine Baby.
I'le fling the Raggs and Tinſel to the Winds,
And let Chance pick 'em up, and give 'em Fools.
Let pride and vanity give Women's hearts
To whom they will; let Deſtiny give Crowns,
Let England now belch fire and o'rewhelm France;
Let Old Time mix the Nations in his Cup
To pleaſe his Palate, and then drink 'em off;
Let Tyrants pour down Rivers of Men's blood,
To grind the World; all this ſhall never reach
My care or thoughts, and when I once am got
Into the ſtill and ſilent room's of Death,
Not all the coyle and rumbling skuffling Nations
Can keep over my Head, will e're wake me.
See! here! the beautious cauſe of my deſtruction,
And weeping! Oh! I have obſerv'd though Pride
Endeavours to fill up her Robe of Glory,
It dragg's in ſorrow, and it doe's not fit her.
Madam.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: He here?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nay, do not fly me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Have I not told you my firm Reſolutions?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Madam you have, but you can change your mind.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: You come with hopes to vex me with new upbraidings.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I come to pleaſe you, with acquainting you
I'me going to free you from this wretch for ever.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Or go, or ſtay, I am indifferent.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Pardon me if I think you are not indifferent.
Iv'e peep'd on the Inſide of your Marriage Chain,
And find it Gold but ſlightly lin'd with Love.
Yes, you have given your ſelf to Pomp, not Love:
To the King's Son, not to the youthful Bridegroom;
You hug not him, but Pharamond and Pippin,
You have married Titles, Crouds, and Noiſe, and Forms,
And now the Lumber hurts you, makes you weep.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I am contented you believe all this.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Well, Madam, Heaven pardon you my ruine.
My Life has ſtream'd or'e Fortunes richeſt Mines,
But ne're did taſte of any thing but Love,
And that ſole ſweetneſs, you make bitter to me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Oh! this is full of Art, twiſting the mind
The wrong ſide outward break's no bones, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Madam, I'me well aſſur'd, you will not ſend
One poor thought after me, much leſs a Meſſenger,
To know the truth, but if you do, he'l find
In ſome unfiniſht part of the Creation,
Where Night and Chaos never were diſturb'd,
And now grown old, are uglier than ever,
And bed-rid, lye, in ſome dark rocky deſart,
There will he find a thing, whether a Man,
Or the collected ſhadows of the Deſert,
Condenſt into a ſhape, he'l hardly know;
This Figure he will find walking alone,
Poring one while on ſome ſad Book, at noon,
By Taper-light, for never day ſhone there.
Sometimes laid groveling on the barren earth,
Moiſt with his Tears, for never Dew fell there.
And when Night comes, not known from Day by darkneſs,
But by ſome faithful Meſſenger of Time,
He'l find him ſtretch't upon a bed of ſtone,
Cut from the bowels of ſome rocky Cave,
Off ring himſelf either to Sleep or Death,
And neither will accept the diſmal Wretch.
At length a ſlumber in its infant Arms,
Take's up his heavy foul, but wanting ſtrength
To bear it, quickly lets it fall again,
At which the Wretch ſtarts up, and walk's about
All night, and all the time it ſhou'd be day,
Till quite forgetting, quite forgot of ev'ry thing
But ſorrow, pines away, and in ſmall time,
Of th' only man that durſt inhabit there,
Becom's the only Ghoſt that dares walk there.
For Ghoſts turn paler when they look that way,
Thus never end's his grief, but now ends yours.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Oh! ſtay, my Lord! What do you mean by this?
Muſt not you blame your ſelf for all the ſorrows
Which we both ſuffer? Had not you firſt thrown
Contempt on me, I wou'd have been your Wife,
Have been your Wife? have rather been a Tree
On which your Name was carv'd, than Queen of France.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How I throw ſcorn on you?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Rude, Publick ſcorn;
Your Army is my Witneſs, your own Hand,
I have it under your own Hand and Seal,
You ſcorn'd my Love, and beg'd releaſe of Vows.

sp.speaker: Du▪
sp.l: Oh! now Hell yawn's, and Treachery appear's

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: He'l kill me.
sp.stage: The Conſtable appears between▪ the Scenes, and ſtops La Guard who is running out.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I'le protect thee.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: I'le be gone.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I'le kill thee then.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: I'me in a fine condition.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I write theſe things! If this right Arm were rotting,
And but to write ſuch things wou'd charm it ſound,
E're I wou'd let it write, I'de let it rot.
You know this too, Why wou'd you credit 'em?
My boſom Friends ſaid you were falſe, and I
Abhor'd 'em all, as men that had the Plague
Of Lying and Slandering, broke out upon 'em,
And I was ready wirh my Sword, to write
Upon their Boſoms, Lord have mercy on 'em.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Beſides a hundred Witneſſes, La Guard's
Acquaintance heard you—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Your acquaintance Miſtreſs?
You are the Witch, I find has rais'd this ſtorm,
Aſſiſted by ſome Devil of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: Oh!—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Tell the Treachery, or I will rip thee,
And ſearch for it in every vein thou haſt.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: Indeed, my Lord, I'me innocent.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt.
No eyes but thine beheld our ſecret Loves,
And none cou'd come behind us but thy ſelf,
And give us ſuch a deadly deadly fall.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: Oh! Pardon me, and I'le confeſs.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: Swear.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Then I ſwear.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: The Dauphin then perceiving
The Princeſs conſtant in her love to you,
Got all thoſe Letters forg'd, brib'd all thoſe Witneſſes
To blaſt your Intereſt, and forc'd me to help him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Enough,—be gon,—had I not ſworn to pardon thee
Yet I muſt do't, Nature give's man a Sacrament,
In his own blood, never to hurt a Woman:
But quickly fly, leſt I break both thoſe Oaths.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Moſt ex'lent Lyar!—To La Gu. between the Scenes.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: Ex'lent Devil you are.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I am decreed, I find, to kill the Dauphin.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: See, in what ſeaſon my Stars bring the Daup.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Weep's, faint's, fall's into the Duke's Arms;
sp.stage: At that inſtant the Conſtable brings in the Dauphin, and ſhews 'em to him.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! Peace, Sir, let us liſten to 'em,
I left 'em kiſſing.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Kiſſing!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Kiſſing cloſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: For this I do abhor and loath the Dauphin.
I am reſolv'd he ne're ſhall touch me more.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Oh! Whore!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Pray ſilence, Sir! For I'de feign have you
Be fully ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: His Love and Glory
Were both to me a taſtleſs Witches Feaſt,
They vaniſhe when ſo e're your Name was nam'd,
Like thoſe Deluſions at the name of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I've heard enough, I'le feaſt you, you damn'd Whom

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: The Dauphin.
sp.stage: Dauphin draw's, wound's Louize, ſhe falls.
The Duke draw's, fight's, diſarm's the Dauphin.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Villain! draw upon thy Prince?
Go call the Guard.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Yes, and I'le call the King,
To let him ſee the Virtues of his Favourite.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: What! Wilt thou kill me, Traytour?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No, I will not.
The Flowers of Graves, and Moſs of Royal Sculls
Protect your Head.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Bold ſlave, talk thus imperiouſly
To a great Prince.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: To a great Prince! a Dwarf,
Whom men wou'd never ſee, did you not ſtand
Upon your Kingly Anceſtors high Monuments.
Oh! Heaven! That I muſt ſee that Beautious Innocence
Rowl in her Blood, and let her Murderer live,
'Cauſe a King got him.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: How! that Beautious Innocence?
That Whore o' thine, but I ha' cool'd her Blood.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Oh! He will pull my Sword upon his Breaſt.

l.hi: As he ſtands in a raging threatning poſture,

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Now, you may ſee, Sir, what a youth this is.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Hold! kill him not, take him alive I charge you.
Your virtuous man here has abus'd my Bed,
And 'cauſe I have diſcover'd him, wou'd murder me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How we are wrong'd!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: You wrong'd?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Yes, by your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: By me? Was ever heard ſuch Impudence?
Away with him.
sp.stage: Exit, a Guard with the Duke.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: What ſhall be done with her?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: I care not what's done with her, let Doggs eat her.
Hold, now I think on't, ſearch her for a Picture.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Sir, here's a Picture newly fallen from her.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Look here, the Picture of her damn'd Adulterer.
This have I ſeen!—Oh! I'me too mad to talk.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I'me carried from my Reaſon with amazement.
In all this ſhame, behold, proud boy, the puniſhment
Of thy bold diſobedience to my Will.
And now for Vendoſme's ſake, I'le never Love
Nor Truſt man more.—

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Away with that lewd Woman.
And now your Son, ſince he boaſt's Innocence,
I will have wrack't, and do you ſee it done.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I ſee it done!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Ay, Sir, if you expect
I keep my Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: If?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Ay! If.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: If.—

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: If.—
I put him upon this to make him odious,
And then I'le throw him off. I know him for
A turbulent great Rogue, and I abhor him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Brought to an If already? I am fool'd.
My Fortunes hung on ſuch a rotten twigg.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: Ha! in diſtraction? What's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Oh! If! if! if!

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: What do you mean by If?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I am poſſeſt, poſſeſt by Fiends call'd Tyrants,
And all my ſtomack's full of Ropes and Axes;
Oh! for a luſty draught of luke-warm Blood,
The Dauphin's blood, to make me throw 'em up.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: I do not underſtand you at all.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: How ſhou'd you?
Your Head and mine hang both upon an If.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: What mean's that If?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: The Dauphin has deluded me,
Has made me tumble down my Son, my Pillar.
Now he's deſtroying me, and you, and all.—

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: Me!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: You.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: The Devil's in your unlucky Friendſhip.
I will take horſe, and out o' Town this minute.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Take Horſe, take Arms!
Go, mount my Son's brave Troops,
And ride 'em o're the Heads of theſe falſe Tyrants.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: They are not ſuch Aſſes to be rid ſo eaſily,
Upon an expedition to the Moon.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Oh! take a Tube, and ſhew 'em all a World
Of Glory in that Moon, and golden Mines there,
Plundering, and Raviſhing; then tell 'em all
They will be all Caſhier'd, and without pay,
Or rather in their General's Coyn be paid,
Be wrack'd for Traytours, torn to ſingle money.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: Muſt he be wrack't?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: By me, his Father.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: Barbarous!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: That grieves me not, I'de make no more to kill
Such a tame Fool, than to ſpill ſo much Milk.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: What, though your Son?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Were all mankind my Children,
I wou'd hang half, to rule the other half.
My Honours! Honours! grieve me: Go—raiſe the Army.
I'me truſted with my Son, and I will tempt him,
Or force him out to 'em; either will do.
If he be with 'em, though in cloſe Confinement
'Twill do, that will be judg'd a ſhew.—Go! go!
He pawſes—ſo!—my Whirle-pool ſucks 'em in.
He ſhall be dipt in this, I'le not come near it.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: He mingles Reaſon ſo with all his Knavery,
None can divide the Ratsbane from the Honey,
And I ſhall ſwallow't, though it rot my Head off.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Rot Head and Tail, and every part o' me,
I had rather loſe 'em all in noble ſtrife,
Than let 'em mouldy in a quiet Life.—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: WHO look's upon this World, and not beyond it,
To the abodes it leads to, muſt believe it
The bloody Slaughter-houſe of ſome Ill Power,
Rather than the contrivance of a Good one.
Ev'ry thing here breeds miſery to man,
The Sea breeds Storms to ſink him. If he flies
To Shore for Ayd, The Shore breeds Rocks to tear him.
The Earth breeds Briars to rend him, Plants to poyſon him,
Beaſts of prey to devour him, Trees to hang him;
Thoſe things that ſeem his Friends, are Falſe to him:
The Air that gives him Breath, gives him Infection.
Meat takes his Health away, and Drink his Reaſon.
His Reaſon is ſo great a boſom plague to him,
He never is ſo pleas'd as when he's rob'd on't
By Drink or Madneſs. Reaſon is an Arrow
Shot in his Head by Nature, to torment him;
And he's in pleaſure when Wine rott's the Arrow,
Or the Moon pull's it out. All things conſpire
The miſery and death of the World's Tyrant;
His Cups are mingled with Sweat, Tears, or Poyſon.
Pain keeps both Doors of this curſed World, and hands
The Tyrant in, and doggs him all the way,
And never leaves him 'till ſhe thruſts him out.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Get the Wrack ready.
sp.stage: A Wrack, a Table, Light, Pen and Paper.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: 'Tis ready.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Bring my Son out.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Here he is,—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Go leave me with him.—So, Sir, are you here?
Now you'l believe my Principles are true.
Who ever wou'd be vertuous, is a Fool;
For he endeavours to plant Vertue here
In a damn'd world, where it no more will grow▪
Than Oranges in Lap-land. It is true,
'Twill peere ſometimes a little above ground,
But never but in dung of poverty;
And then it ſmell's ſo ill, People of Quality
Ne're take it in their Boſom's.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Nay, the projecting fool that aims at Vertue,
Is a ridiculous Chymiſt, that wou'd make
A vertuous thing out of a Man or Woman,
Who have not a grain of honeſty about 'em;
And they have ſome parts can never be made honeſt.
Nay, there is no falſe fellow like your fool.
Who wou'd be virtuous? for your ſteady Villain
Who ſticks at nothing, is moſt true to every thing;
But your lame fool who halt's 'tween Vice and Vertue,
Is falſe to both, and ſo is true to nothing,
And ſo has no Friends in Heaven or Hell,
And that's the reaſon he never thrives.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Oh! Divine Maximes theſe!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Sir, they are true.
Perhaps there never were ſuch things as Vertue's,
But only in men's Fancies like the Phenix.
Or if they once have been, they'r now but Names
Of Natures loſt, which came into the World,
But cou'd not live nor propagate their kind.
How ſhou'd they propagate? Your virtuous fellow
Is an Hermophradite, he has two Sexes.
Virtue and Vice, and ſuch a Monſter thou art:
To glory thou art a Girle, but to Woman
Thou art a vig'rous Man! Oh! thou poor ſinner!
To ſcorn Ambition, the ſin of Angels,
And ſtoop to be a Goat.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This Accuſation
Ha's no more truth than any of your Maximes.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Deny it? You do'nt know you ſhall be Wrack'd?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Be Wrack'd!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Be Wrack'd.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You bring a Bed agreeing
To the fine Lodging you have provided for me.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: It is a Bed the Dauphin has provided you,
Where you muſt lye, till you confeſs your Crimes,
Your Treaſon, and Adultery.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Do's the Dauphin
Give his fair murder'd Princeſs this embalming,
To wrap her up in ſtinking defamation?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! I ſhall ſupple your ſtiff humour.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Never.
You'l ſooner carve me into a Toad than Lyar.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Will you talk thus upon the Wrack and Scaffold?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: On both; and more: I will affirm the Dauphin
Wrong'd us, and not we him.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This is Truth.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: If this be Truth, then am I finely fool'd.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I know not that, but I am deeply wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Then ſo am I, wrong'd, fool'd, deluded, gull'd,
To drink my own Son's blood hot from his Veins,
That I may ſmell moſt rank to all mankind,
And have Doggs fly at me where e're I go.
Oh! barb'rous! made to murder my own Son,
A Valiant young man, a wiſe young man,
An Innocent young man.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more, my Lord.
There's alwayes ſome Venome in your Paint,
You ne're Guilded any but in hopes to Rot 'em,
You never Stroke a Head, but it Fall's off.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Is it my Heart, or all the City Trembles?
Oh! that ſome Earthquake now wou'd make all Paris,
Rowle, and o're-lay her Children in their ſleep,
Kill all of 'em but this young man and me.
What need I wiſh for Slaughter? there will be
Enough to night, and let it be for me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What doe's he mean now? there is in his breaſt
A reſtleſs, bottomleſs, black Sea of wickedneſs,
And I muſt dive into't— [Aſide] What is your meaning?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Tis this; Your Troops, the City, the Nobility,
Both out of Love to You, and Hate to Tyranny,
Demand your Life, or clear Proofs of your Crimes,
Elſe they reſolve to fill up with their Swords
The Gap your Death will make for Tyranny
To flow upon 'em; I, who thought you guilty,
Was cheated by theſe Tyrants, to come hither
And Wrack you into a Lyar, to ſave them.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why did I plunge into his Breaſt, a Sea
Wou'd make the Devil ſick if he flew over it,
And tumble like a Bird that flies o're Jordan?
Oh! how I am confounded?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Ha! I ſee
Loyalty ſtrugling in thy noble Nature
For a brave lye to ſave thy Prince from danger.
Do what thou wilt, for my part, I'le not counſel thee;
'Tis true, you wou'd do well to ſave your Prince,
For it will breed ſtrange Gangreens all o're France,
To have a Great Man ſhuffled out of Life,
They can't tell how to pleaſe the Dauphin's envy;
And yet, me-thinkes, to ſave him by acknowledging
Your ſelf a Villain, and the Princeſs Whore!
Oh! out upon't! I'de let the Kingdom periſh
E're I wou'd be a Dog to lick its Sores
With a foule Tongue.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Oh! How does he diſtract me?—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I ſee that Paper draws thy kind Eye towards it,
Thou haſt a mind to be ſcribling,—take it.
But you muſt write down all the Circumſtances,
How oft, and when, and where, you enjoyed the Princeſs.
Ha! You reſolve then rather to be torn,
And let the King be torn too, like this Paper.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nor that.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I will go Head my Troops.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Ha! Now thou ſpeak'ſt indeed? Thou art caſt anew
Into the very mettle I wou'd have thee.
Ring out that Bell, that paſſing Bell of Tyranny.
Proclaim thy Innocence by Trumpet's Sounds,
And with thy Sword and Pike bore all deaf Ears.
If thou muſt go into another world,
Go like a Gallant man, not creepingly
Like a poor Rogue into a Houſe by night,
Through Grates and Holes will tare thy fleſh to Raggs,
And make thy Friends in Heaven aſham'd to own thee.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Which way ſhall I get hence?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: In my own Chair,
We will go both together out, unknown.
My Chair,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Will you go with me to the Army?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: No, I'le preſerve a certain Friend for thee
In caſe uncertain Fortune prove thy Enemy.
Go out a while,—To the Chair-men:

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I want a Sword.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Take mine.
sp.stage: The Conſtable gives the Duke his Sword, who draws it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Now know, my Lord, I've once out-witted you,
I've div'd into you, and I find your Plots,
You have ſtir'd up my Army to Rebellion,
And now you fain wou'd fool me out to Head 'em.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: A Guard there.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Silence! Or you ne're ſpeak more.
I know the Reverence I ow a Father;
I'le no more violate you than an Altar;
But we may wipe away dirt from an Altar,
And I wou'd free you from this dirty World
In whoſe foul Womb you labour like a Mole,
And when you'r dragg'd into the Light of Innocence,
You are ſick, like things out of their Element.
Since no perſwaſions then can make you Honeſt,
Nor keep you Quiet, Locks and Walls ſhall do it,
Both for my Prince's ſake, and for your own.
Into the Chair, ſo with me to the King.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! Slave!

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Into the Chair.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Prieſt-ridden Slave!
Who all thy inſipid Life haſt been transfuſing
The ſheepiſh thoughts of Prieſts into thy head,
Doſt know no way but what thoſe wooden Hands
Direct thee to.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Into the Chair.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I heard
A Lover, once in a Rapture, tell his Miſtreſs
Her Mother fed on Roſes; ſure when I
Got thee I was confin'd to a milk diet.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Into the Chair.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I'le not into the Chair.
sp.stage: Draws a long Tuck out of a Cane.
sp.l: I am provided for you, Sir; a Guard there.—
Secure this Traytor here, he has diſarm'd me
To make eſcape; Now, Sir, I'le handle you.
Bind him, and get the Wrack prepar'd with ſpeed.
Oh! thou Fool! Fool! ridiculous, vertuous Fool;
I cannot ſpeak my mind, I ſhall betray my ſelf.
Thou mightſt have been King!

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A glorious Villain.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Crown'd on that Scaffold where thy Head ſhall fall.

sp.speaker: Gu.
sp.l: My Lord, the Wounded Princeſs does deſire
Admiſſion to the Duke, ſhe ſays ſhe has
Some things of Conſequence ſhe wou'd reveal.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: They are guilty then? and ſhe is a Strumpet,—
Admit her.—
sp.stage: Enter Louize in a Chair, her Woman helps her out.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Oh! My Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Help her, ſhe faints!
In ſuch fair Ruines Heaven would have lain
If the ill Angels had ſubdu'd the good.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Such a Groan a breaking Sphere wou'd give.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How does my Love?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Exceeding ill;
And yet not ill enough for one whoſe ſins
Has brought ſuch ills on you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Your Sins?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Oh yes!
My Pride and Jealouſie did ruine both of us;
'Twas wicked Sacriledge to let hot Rage
Melt down your Golden Image in my mind.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Your Love, which never wander'd once from me
Where it was born, doe's talk of me as thoſe
Do of their Native Country's who ne're travel'd.
I cannot talk or think too much of you;
The thoughts you Lov'd me once, will make me think my ſelf
Above an Angel, and this ſight of you
Make me diſreliſh all the Heavenly Viſions.
I ſay this openly before the World;
I ſcorn to tarry till we meet in Death
And whiſper it behind the Globe in private.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Did e're till now two Lovers find ſuch Joys
In the cold barren ſpace between two Worlds?
How do theſe Pleaſures guild the Gates of Death,
Make pleaſant Walkes to lead up to the Shades?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: This is the Innocent Pair.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Unnatural Tyrant!
My Soul is often comming to my Wound,
And ſeeing you, ſtart's back, and think's you Hell.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I find your Wound has much corrupted Blood in't,

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I faint.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Oh! help.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Farwell, thou Paradiſe;
I'me driven from thee by a Flaming Sword,
And for the ſin of Eve, believing Lyes,
But to a better World than Eve was chas't,
To Heaven! There's one, no doubt: for were there none,
There wou'd be one o' purpoſe made for you.—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: She's going! She's gone! whilſt th' iron Hand
Of Death, broke this fair Diamond in pieces,
What Sparks flew round, each Richer than a World?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: What do I ſee! Oh! Torment! Torment! Hell!
How durſt you ſuffer this?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Sir, ſhe deſir'd
Admiſſion on pretence ſhe wou'd Confeſs,
And only came to Dye in his Embraces.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Oh! Hot Egyptian Luſt! a Luſt which burn's
In Damp's of Death, and makes the Grave a Brothel.
Vendoſme! You till this Moment, like a Torrent,
Have born me down like a ſmall floating Weed,
But here you ſhall run under Ground for ever.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But I ſhall riſe again in Paradiſe,
Where I ſhall mixe with this Pure Stream for ever.
But Sir, you take his Life who gave you Yours.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Thou give me Life? Yes, as the Crows and Ravens
Give me my Eyes, they dare not pick e'm out.
Thou Buzzard durſt not light on me an Eagle,
For thy laſt Perch thou knew'ſt wou'd be a Gibbet.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sir, I'le boldly tell you more; In me
You fling away the Fortune of the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: If France's Fortune be ſo Beggarly,
Then I do well to fling it on a Dunghil.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: The Crown you hope to Heir, hang's on this Arm.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: I'd ſcorn to wear a Feather that had hung
On ſuch a Pin.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: That Scorn, a Rod ſhall Scourge,
Cut from the Cypreſs that ſhall ſhade my Tombe.
Shortly you'l ſtrive to make another me
Out of my Duſt, mingled with all my Tears,
And all your Souls: But my proud Duſt will ſlight you.
My loſs is nothing but a World, which alwayes
Appear'd to me, a painted treacherous Whore,
That lead's to Hell the Fools and Knaves that love her,
And is a Hell to the Brave Men that ſcorn her.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Sir, for the Satisfaction of the World
You muſt confeſs your Crimes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You know us Innocent.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: How dar'ſt thou tell me this? Doſt thou not ſee
That Wrack there? Ha!—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Yes, and I ſee 'tis Wood,
A Limb of ſome old fallen Son of Earth;
And I will not be made to ſpeak a Falſhood
By any Sons of Earth, or Sons of Kings.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Intollerable! lead him to the Wrack.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: You ſee how faithfully I've ſerv'd you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Againſt your Son.—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, I've gone indeed
Againſt the ſtream of Nature to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Can I then think thou wilt be true to me?
If thou could'ſt go ſo eaſily to Miſchief,
When thou wert ſhackled with the Chains of Nature,
How ſwiftly wilt thou run when thou art free?
Know Fool, I've made thee work thy own deſtruction,
I've thrown thee at thy Son, and made you daſh
Each other in pieces like two Earthen Veſſels.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Ha! did you mean by Favours which you promis'd me,
Only to make me Hangman to my Son?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Princes no more ſhou'd keep their words with Villains
Than Prieſts with Hereticks.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! Horrour! horrour!
I have fed your Revenge with my Blood's Quinteſſence,
The Blood of him I got in my hot Youth,
And now you break your League, and ſeek my Life.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: I ſcorn thy wither'd Life, let it drop from thee,
Thy wickedneſs can do no further Miſchief,
Except it work Confuſion in the Heavens,
And make the Sun with horrour hide his Head.
But Nature now is us'd to barbrous deeds,
They do not ſcare her into dire Miſcarriages,
Nor make her Womb conceive unſhapen Prodigies:
Now thou maiſt eat thy Son, the Prince of Day
Is hardy grown, and will not faint and look
As girliſh as he did at Atreus Feaſt.
Perhaps that Eye of Day is dimme with Age,
Then live, but live in quiet.—Guard ſecure him.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! Ruine! Death! I've torn my Bowels out
To hoyſe my ſelf into this Tyrants Favour,
And I've only made my Fall more deadly.
Hoys'd did I call it? rather, then I fell,
When I became a Man, to be a Great One,
Became a Dog to wear a Silver Collar.
I am a Dog, and I am running mad
With drinking the hot Blood of my own Young.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Ha! What mean's this?

sp.speaker: Briſac.
sp.l: The Duke of Vendoſm's Troops.
Are by our treacherous Guards let in upon us;
That, Sir, you have no ſafety but in Flight.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Oh Villaines!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! moſt ſeaſonable Rogues!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Oh Villaines!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! moſt ſeaſonable Rogues!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: I'le fall on 'em be the event what it will.
That Prince who fear's deſerves not to be fear'd,
Nor to be greater than that Man who dares
Do greater things than he. Secure that Traytor.
sp.stage: Enter the Great Conſtable, La Force, young Captains; the Dauphin, and Briſac Priſoners.

sp.speaker: Canſt.
sp.l: Oh! you brave Heroe's, greater each than Brutus,
He but repair'd, you build your Country's Freedom:
Till now, a Frenchman, ſcarce deſerv'd to come
Into the preſence of a Roman Statue.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: I find the Conſtable will be the man,
I am reſolved I will chop in with him.
My Lord, I beg your pardon for paſt Errours,
I find the Court has injur'd both of us:
I'le gladly ſerve you with my Life and Fortune
If youl accept of 'em.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: In my condition
I ſhall have great occaſion for a Raſcal,
Therefore I will accept thee.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: I will ſerve you.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: Where is the Duke?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Ay! there's the queſtion,
Here in this flaughter-houſe is a torn Wrecth,
Some ſay is he; his Father know's him not.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How? a torn Wretch?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Ah! Sirs, cou'd you collect
In one dire figure all the ghaſtly Horrours
E're cover'd Field, after the bloodieſt Battel,
When one vaſt paleneſs ſpreads the Earth's green Table,
And Faces folded up in different Grinnes,
With barbarous Ornament adorn it round,
And Bodies pil'd prepare a gluttonous Feaſt
For Birds and Beaſts of prey, it wou'd not be
So terrible a ſight as this I ſhew you.
sp.stage: The Scene drawn, The Duke is ſhew'd wrack't, Louize dead by him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Oh! Horrour! Fire the Louvre!

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: Proclaim Liberty;
Freedom is born, Chriſten it with Tyrants blood.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Hold! I command you, hold.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: What's your will?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My will is you refine, and turn Barbarians!
What Savage Nation in the World, retains not
In the disfigured maſs of Humane Nature
Reverence to Princes? If it be too hard
To be as poliſh't as Barbarians,
Be but as good and honeſt as tame Beaſts,
They 're gentle and ſubmiſſive to their Maſters;
But if you will be Men, Subjects, and Souldiers,
Fall at your Prince's Feet, and ask him pardon,
Or throw me dead at yours, do one of 'em,
Or in ſmall time, I'le throw you dead at mine,
For I have loyal Troops that will obey me.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: His pains diſtract him.

sp.speaker: La For.
sp.l: What do you mean, my Lord?
You have had great Injuries.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What's that to you?
But I've had none: My preſent ſufferings
Are what appearances gave warrant for.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: You are wrong'd,
And do not rob your ſelf of juſt Revenge.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nor ſhall you all here rob me of my Honour;
Though like baſe Thieves you watch your opportunity
When I am all o▪ fire, and laid in Rumes.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: He's mad! ſtark raving mad, Sir's do not mind him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ho! Guard▪ convey me to my loyal Troops,
Thoſe ſhall obey me, impriſon me, or kill me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We kneel, we kneel! We beg your Highneſs pardon.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Now ſeize my Father.—All kneel to the Dauphin.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Was e're Man ſo Brave?—

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: The King is coming hither.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Meet him all,
And fall at his Feet.
sp.stage: The Dauphin, Briſac, and the Caprains go out, Shouts within. After a pawſe all re-enter, following the King.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The Truth appears too late! Oh! thou raſh youth!
Thou haſt deſtroy'd the joys of both our Lives,
A noble innocent Pair! for they are Innocent!
Bring in the Traytreſs who deſtroyd 'em both.

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: Oh! Bloud! Bloud follow's me, I'le confeſs all,
And beg for Death, no Hell like a bad Conſcience.
The Princeſs was contracted to the Duke
Long e're the Dauphin lov'd her.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: How? Contracted?

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: Yes Sir; but e're they cou'd compleat the Marriage,
You ſent away the Duke, to ayd the Germans
Againſt the Turks, in the mean while your Paſſion
For her began; the Conſtable perceiving it,
Hoping to draw the Duke from his Allegiance,
Knowing that no Temptation elſe cou'd do it,
Brib'd me, and others, wicked as my ſelf,
To aid him, in obtaining her for You.
We counterfeited the Duke's Hand exactly,
And wrote in it provoking Letters to her,
Then we invented Lyes of the Duke's fal • hood,
And by theſe Arts ſo turn'd her haughty mind,
That ſhe ſoon hated him, and lov'd your Highneſs.
When this was done, the Conſtable compell'd me
To lay his tricks and forgeries on you.
Then went and kindled a fierce jealouſy in you,
And brought you on th' unhappy innocent pair,
When they were only mourning for their wrongs.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: O! horrid! horrid!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh! notorious falſhood!

sp.speaker: La Gu.
sp.l: The truth ſhall out, Sir, the vile Conſtable
Lodg'd all theſe villainous Secrets in my Boſom.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Was ever ſuch a Villain?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Every Man.
Is ſuch a Villain, who is not a Fool.
Had that damn'd Sot been Lord of half my wit,
He had this hour been Lord of all the Kingdom.
To ſhew the difference in our Underſtandings,
Mine wou'd have made him King, his noble Wit
Has made himſelf a very gallant Fellow.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: No, thy unnatural Villany wrought this.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I own I twiſted all thoſe various Cables.
To drag that lump of Lead up to a Throne,
And he has broke 'em all. Indeed there is
Too much already of that droſſy Metal
Over the State; the Church is always cover'd with it,
And I deſign'd to melt it down, and place
On top of Church and State rich Gold, my ſelf;
But dragging him up with me, broke my Pullies.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Impudent arrogance!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: A Corpſe, they ſay,
Carried to Sea, does always breed a Storm.
I wafting this dead Fool o're to a Kingdom,
Have ſhipwrack'd all the Glories I was laden with.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Away, with him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Pray give him, Sir, his Life,

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: How? haſt thou thrown me on hooks, as Turks do ſlaves?
Then would'ſt thou have me hang alive in torments?
No, I will rather have my Limbs feed Crows,
Then poorly live to be the ſcorn of Fools.
For a wiſe Man the Image of a God,
To creep to Fools, ſcarce Images of Men;
I'le as ſoon worſhip golden Calves with Jews,
Or with the Sumatrans a Monkeys Tooth.
My Glory, that ha's kept me ever waking,
Is out, now ſend me t'eternal darkneſs.
And young man, do you pray, pray heartily,
Be ſure you get to Heaven, for if your piety
Shou'd crack, and let you fall to Hell where I am,
I'le plague you worſe than all the Devils there.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What a black Demon had I ne're my Throne?

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: Now will I fix my ſelf.
The Constable a Priſoner!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Seize that fellow.
You ſhall be hang'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: Oh! Sir.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: Yes, Sirrah, you are a great Rogue.

sp.speaker: La Ma.
sp.l: You wou'd not hang me were I a great Rogue.
Well 'tis as fooliſh to play Villany
As Money, with a Man of a great Stock,
He can throw out and out, and ſtill play on,
We once throw out, we are thrown to the Devil,
Whither they come at laſt, for when all's done
The Devil's Box get's all.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: My poor Louize.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Noble Youth!
Haſt thou had ſuch great wrongs; yet give my Son
His Life, and me my Crown?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Princes are ſacred,
What e're Religion Rebels may pretend,
Murderers of Kings are Worſhippers of Devils,
For none but Devils are worſhip • by ſuch Sacrifices.
They who derive all Power from the People,
Do baſely baſterdiſe it with that Buckle •
Which fell from Heaven to protect Innocence.
They protect Villany, No ſacrilege
Greater, then when a Rebel with his Sword
Dare's cut the hand of Heaven from King's Commiſſions,
To hide the Devil's mark upon his own.
I lifted up my Arm againſt the Dauphin,
It ought to have dy'd and rotted in the Air.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: I fully pardon you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Then I dye joyfully.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Talk'ſt thou of Dying:

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I received two Wounds
In the laſt Battle, Sir, upon my Breaſt,
Which now are torn far into Deaths Dominions.
sp.stage: The Duke ſhows his Breast bloody.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Oh! miſerable Sight!

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Oh! blaſting Sight!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Here falls a Pharaoh's Tower, Epheſian Temple,
The Coſt of Ages, Wonder of Eternity.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You guild a vaniſhing Shadow.—
May I have leave, Sir,—To the Dauphin.
To ſleep in Death by her who was your Princeſs?
But in the Grave there's no Propriety,
In Death's dark ruinous Empire all lye's waſte.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.l: You ſhall have that, and all befitting Honours.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then come cold Bride to my as cold Embrace,
The Grave's our Bed, and Death our Bridal-Night,
None will diſturb, or envy our Delight.—

div.head: THE EPILOGUE, Spoken by Mr. Haines, who Acted La Marre.

l.hi: FInding ſad Plays ſo good ſucceſs have bad;
To make this Tragedy exceeding ſaid,
The Author doom'd me to be hang'd to Night;
But now I hop'd I ſhou'd be hang'dout right.
For I've three plagues no fleſh and blood can bear,
I am a Poet, Married, and a Player.

div.l: A Wife ha's e're ſince Eve been thought an evil,

l.hi: The firſt that danc'd at Weddings was the Devil.
At the firſt Wedding all Mankind miſcarried,

div.l: Old Adam ne're was wicked 'till he married.

l.hi: And Poetry of curſes never fail'd.

div.l: Homer his Rags on all his race entail'd.

l.hi: He was an old blind Beggar and ſo poor,
He ſtarv'd the Dog that led him, and the Curre
To have revenge on Poets, got in ſpite

div.l: Criticks, who worry all that dare to write.

l.hi: But 'till of late a Player was a toy
That either ſex lik'd well enough, t▪ enjoy;
Happy the Spark that cou'd a Night carouſe
With a whole Sharer once of either Houſe.
Nay Women once in our acquaintance crept;
You hardly will believe me,—I was kept.
But I, and all of us, are fallen ſo low;
Nothing will keep us but Bum Bailiffs now.
Now no divertiſement do'es pleaſure bring,
The Pope ha's ſet his foot in ev'ry thing.
His Prieſts and Poets have conſpir'd our fall,
Priests by bad Plots, Poets by none at all.
And Poets like the Jeſuits of the times,
Will hang and damn e're they will own their Crimes.

div.l: Like Fryan Bacon's Brazen Head, they'l ſpeak

l.hi: Just what they pleaſe and then in peices break.
'Tis strange fond Nature often takes great pains,
To build Braſs Fore-heads to defend no brains.
Well, Sirs, damn Plays and Poets as you pleaſe,
But pray ſupp • rt a Play-houſe for your eaſe.

div.l: Ladies ſome Journeys to Hide. Park may ſpare,

l.hi: Our empty Play-Houſe ha's enough freſh Air.
And Gallants pray ſupport us not for Plays,
But to find Ladies here in rainy days.
